catalysts Yves Chauvin, Andre Hirschauer, Helene Olivier Institut Francais du Petrole, BP 311, 92506 Rueil-Malmaison, France, fax (+33-1)47526055, E-mail CHAUVIN@ IRVAXI IFP FR Received 21 February 1994, revised 14 March 1994, accepted 14 March 1994 Abstract Isobutane was alkylated with 2-butene, to batchwise conditions, using liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride-aluminium chloride molten salts as the acidic catalyst The effect of the operating variables on the product composition has been investigated The control of the acidity of the catalyst has made possible the production of a high quality alkylate Key words Alkylation, Butenes, Isobutane, Molten salts, Organochloroalurtunates 1. Introduction Isobutane alkylation is one of the most important processes for producing reformulated gasoline Commercial alkylation plants use either sulfuric acid or hydrogen fluoride as catalysts The advantages and disadvantages of the two processes have often been debated alkylate quality, cooling and separation problems, operating costs, safety aspects [ 1 ] Aluminium chloride based catalysts have been described for a long time as much more active catalysts than conventional ones. However, due to the high acidity of aluminium chloride, side reactions such as cracking, disproportionation and isomenzation are important To reduce the acidity of aluminium chloride some "bases" such as alkali metal chloride, methanol, ether, aromatic hydrocarbons and/or certain metal chlorides have been added [2-4] We have anticipated that another way to control the acidity of alummium chloride consists in adding tetrasubstituted ammonium chlorides Mixtures of aluminium 0304-5102/94/$07 00 1994 Elsevier Science B V All rights reserved SSDI0304-5102(94)00065-4 156 Yves Chauvin et al /Journal of Molecular Catalyses 92 (1994) 155-165 chloride and alkylpyndinium chlorides or dialkylimidazolium chlorides are liquid at room temperature and below, over a wide range of compositions These melts have received considerable attention in many electrochemical applications such as electrolytes in batteries or aluminium electroplating baths [ 5 ] One very attractive feature of these systems is that their Lewis acidity can easily be adjusted by varying the aluminium molar fraction present in the system For example, they can be considered as basic when the alummium chloride molar fraction contained in the melt (denoted N) is lower than 0 5, and acidic for N > 0 5 It has been demonstrated that anionic species present in the acidic organohaloaluminate molten salts are AICl4 , A12CI7 and A13CI10 Lewis acidity originates from dissociation of AIC13 from di- and trimenc anions Quantitative determination of the acidic properties of these media has been done by IR and UV spectral shifts of organoiron complexes containing CO and -CN ligands [6], by 3'P NMR chemical shift of tnethylphosphine oxide [ 7 ] and lastly by 'H NMR chemical shift of the cyclopentadienyl protons in Cp2MC12 (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) [ 8 ] In a previous paper we described the use of molten salts based on butylmethylimidazolium chloride and aluminium chloride for isobutane alkylation with ethylene [ 9 ] The present paper reports the results we obtained in the alkylation of isobutane with 2-butene catalyzed by the same molten salts 2. Experimental Haloaluminate molten salts were prepared as previously described [ 5 ] All the alkylation experiments were carried out in a 250 ml-capacity FischerPorter flask immersed in a cooling bath ( t 0 5 C) In all experiments the rate of agitation was constant and ensured by a magnetic stirring bar A stainless steel cylindrical grid (25 mesh) was fixed inside the flask to improve the dispersion of the ionic phase into the hydrocarbon phase A sufficient amount (e g , 70 g) of abutane-butane mixture (containing a small amount of water, approx 60 ppm) was charged, before starting, into the reactor containing the molten salt (7 ml) in order to insure good mixing at the reaction start-up Thus the volumetric ratio of acid to hydrocarbon phases was much lower than that generally used in sulfuric acid catalyzed alkylation The feedstock, a mixture of a-butane, butane (internal standard not modified during the reaction) and 2-butene (mixture of cis and trans isomers) was contained in a 100 ml Fischer-Porter flask and stored over 3 A molecular sieves The isobutane to 2-butene ratio in the feed was 1 5 The feed was continuously fed through a microvalve into the reactor The addition rate was defined as the volume of pure liquid 2-butene per volume of molten salt contained in the reactor per hour (LHSV) During an experiment, from time to time, stirring was stopped, the molten salt was decanted and aliquots of the hydrocarbon phase were withdrawn for analysis In this way, it was possible to obtain various isobutane conversions When the reactor was full (150 g), all the hydrocarbon upper phase Yves Chauvin et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 92 (1994) 155-165 Molecular Sievle r u Microvalve Coolinq bath Reactor _- Gzid I-- Alkylate I-_ Molten salt Fig 1 Results It is obvious that in systems consisting of two liquid phases mass transfer is of great importance In an alkylation reaction, physical phenomena associated with acid/ hydrocarbon volume ratio and agitation have a strong effect on the quality and composition of the alkylate In order to compare our results with more conventional sulfuric acid catalyzed alkylation and despite the difference between the density and viscosity of the two catalysts, preliminary experiments were performed in the designed apparatus with 96% fresh sulfuric acid The results are reported in Table 2 Compared to the product distribution described in the literature [ 10], we produced a higher content of both light ends (CS to C7 isoparaffins) and heavy ends (C9+ isoparaffins), and lower amount of total TMP's The distribution of the different TMP isomers was not significantly affected Such results were not surprising due to the less favorable operating conditions (agitation, acid to hydrocarbon volume ratio) compared to those used in industrial processes. Discussion of the results The general characteristics of the alkylatlon reaction catalyzed by aluminium chloride based salts are very similar to those previously observed with conventional liquid catalysts, I e , sulfuric and hydrogen fluoride acids (1) hydride transfer, then the yield of TMP's, increases with increasing acid strength, (11) low acidity probably favors proton transfer, then the formation of olefinlc compounds that are responsible for the formation of heavy ends, (111) at high acid strength cracking reactions become important and the level of light ends increases, (IV) increasing the temperature decreases the TMP's content Thus in order to obtain good selectivities the acidity of the catalyst has to be carefully controlled It has been found that HO dissolved in an acidic organochloroalumlnate molten salt is a Bronsted superacld, comparable in strength to e g , 100% HZS04 [ 11,12] lO Yves Chauvin et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994)155-165 Increasing the concentration of HCl and/or the molar fraction of AIC13 In the melt increased the Hammett acidity function to -15 (like liquid HF) and even to -18 Adding water in an acidic molten salt played a similar, but more complex, role to HCl [ 13 ] Thus, there are two ways of increasing the acidity of the melts, I e , increasing either the molar fraction of A1C13 or the concentration of protons Increasing the content of protons by increasing the level of water (in our case, water was dissolved in the isobutane used before starting the reaction and, sometimes, for washing the molten salts after every run) resulted in an increase in the butene conversion and a decrease in the rate of side reactions The same trends were observed by increasing the AIC13 molar fraction An important advantage of molten salts, compared to conventional AIC13 based catalysts, is that their acidity can be tuned with great precision, since they are liquid over a wide range of compositions Thus this is one of the most useful variables in maximizing alkylate quality In contrast to sulfunc acid alkylation, a good alkylate can be obtained with a not very good agitation (stirring bar) On the other hand, formation of "red oils" is minimized 5.
